Boosting propene oxidation activity over LaFeO3 perovskite catalysts by cobalt substitution Feng Pan a Weidong Zhang a Corinne Ferronato a José Luis Valverde b Anne Giroir-Fendler a ⁎ a Univ. Lyon, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, CNRS, IRCELYON, 2 Avenue Albert Einstein, Villeurbanne F-69622, France Univ. Lyon, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, CNRS, IRCELYON 2 Avenue Albert Einstein Villeurbanne F-69622 France Univ. Lyon, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, CNRS, IRCELYON, 2 Avenue Albert Einstein, Villeurbanne, F-69622, France b Department of Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Chemical Science and Technology, University of Castilla-La Mancha, Avenida Camilo José Cela 12, 13005 Ciudad Real, Spain Department of Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Chemical Science and Technology, University of Castilla-La Mancha Avenida Camilo José Cela 12 Ciudad Real 13005 Spain Department of Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Chemical Science and Technology, University of Castilla-La Mancha, Avenida Camilo José Cela 12, 13005, Ciudad Real, Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. To develop robust and cost-effective catalysts for propene total oxidation, LaFe1−xCoxO3 (x = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 1) perovskites were prepared via a citrate sol-gel method. XRD, FTIR and Raman analyses suggested that after cobalt substitution, the LaFeO3 structure was well maintained, whereas abundant lattice distortions were generated accompanied by weaker Fe−O bond. H2-TPR and O2-TPD results demonstrated that cobalt incorporation led to better reducibility and higher oxygen mobility of the oxides. The propene oxidation activity of the catalysts was found to increase with the cobalt content, which correlated well with the amount of surface-active oxygen species. The optimal catalyst LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 presented comparable activity to LaCoO3 at much lower cost. Moreover, it showed excellent cyclability (6 cycles) and stability (35 h), decent performance at high space velocity (24,0000 mL g–1 h–1) or in the presence of 5 vol% water, thereby being a promising candidate for industrial application. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords LaFeO3 perovskite Cobalt substitution VOCs Propene oxidation 1 Introduction Perovskite-type oxides with the general formula of ABO3 have been widely used in electrocatalysis [1], photocatalysis [2], gas sensor [3], solar cell [4,5], and catalytic oxidation [6,7]. Particularly, due to their cheap price, tunable redox ability, high thermal stability, and oxygen mobility, perovskite-type oxides have been considered alternatives to noble metal in the catalytic combustion of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) [8], especially when applied at high temperatures, oxygen and steam-rich conditions [9]. In a typical ABO3 structure, A-site cations are composed of large-radii rare-earth metals or alkali metals with 12-fold coordination and are considered catalytically inert; for its part, B-site cations are usually transition metals with the 3d, 4d or 5d configuration occupying 6-fold coordination sites, which play a vital role in catalytic oxidation due to their superior redox ability [10,11]. Since lanthanides in A site produce a highly stable structure and have minor influence on catalysis, lanthanum-based perovskites have been extensively studied, demonstrating a remarkable performance in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs and CH4 [12–16]. Generally, specific surface area, redox properties and oxygen mobility of perovskites are closely related to their catalytic activity in VOCs oxidation [17,18]. To improve the catalytic activity of La-based perovskites, different strategies have been proposed, such as hierarchical structure construction [19,20], morphology control [21] and A-site/B-site substitution [22,23]. Comparatively, partial substitution of A-/B- site by other metal elements with similar radii is a simple but effective strategy to modify the physicochemical properties of the perovskites. Partial substitution of La could result in the charge imbalance at B site, accompanied by defects and oxygen vacancies formation [12,24]. Luo et al. [25] found that substituting partial La by Ce in LaCoO3 helped produce higher valance Co and led to enhanced benzene oxidation activity. Liu et al. [15] introduced urea in the traditional citrate preparation process of LaMnO3.15 and achieved an in-situ regulation of La vacancy by NH4 + replacement, which resulted in an increase of the Mn4+ concentration and better toluene oxidation activity. On the other hand, the substitution of B-site with more reducible metal would directly enhance the redox property of perovskite [26,27]. Zhang et al. [28] prepared a series of Ni-substituted LaMnO3 catalysts for propane combustion and ascribed the boosted catalytic performance to the better redox ability and higher average oxidation state of Mn. Flores-Lasluisa et al. [29] discovered that high cobalt-substitution levels in LaMnO3 could generate more high valence state Co3+ and Mn4+. Among the La-based perovskites, LaFeO3 exhibited inferior catalytic activity to LaCoO3 and LaMnO3 because of the lower reducibility and oxygen mobility of LaFeO3. Nevertheless, LaFeO3 aroused particular interest from many researchers due to the low cost, earth abundance and non-toxicity characteristics of iron [30]. In addition, LaFeO3 can afford long-term operation at a higher temperature thanks to its better thermal stability [31]. Therefore, it is highly desired to activate and improve the catalytic activity of LaFeO3. There have been several attempts, e.g. acid treatment [32,33], noble metal loading [34] and A-/B- substitution [35,36]. Wu et al. [33] modified the surface of LaFeO3 by nitric acid to expose more Fe-O termination, which helped boost the reducibility and oxygen mobility of LaFeO3, thus achieving higher toluene oxidation activity. Eyssler et al. [37] investigated the methane combustion activity of 2 wt% Pd/LaFeO3 calcined at different temperatures and showed the crucial role that the Pd−LaFeO3 interaction played in the oxidation. Wu et al. [38] implemented A or/and B-site substitutions of LaFeO3 to modulate the oxidation state of B-site and the oxygen mobility through structural distortions, thereby improving the catalytic activity of LaFeO3 in gasoline engines. To the best of our knowledge, there are not many references related to the propene oxidation over LaFeO3 perovskite. As a representative VOC, propene possesses a high potential to produce photochemical ozone and is one of the most challenging and harmful environmental pollutants because it is commonly presented in the chemical industry, motor vehicle, and aircraft exhausts [39]. Herein, we introduced a more active but expensive metal cobalt (74,000 USD/mt) into the LaFeO3 system (141.76 USD/mt iron) to obtain a cost-effective catalysts [40]. A series of LaFe1−xCoxO3 (x = 0 −0.3) was synthesized via a citrate method, carefully characterized by various techniques, and used as catalysts in the deep oxidation of propene. The effects of space velocity, water vapor, propane co-presence, and inlet reactant concentrations on the performance of a typical catalyst were also investigated. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Synthesis LaFeO3, LaCoO3 and LaFe1−xCoxO3 (x = 0.1, 0.2, 0.3) were synthesized by the citric acid method. La(NO3)3·6H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (Sigma-Aldrich) were used as metal precursors. First, stoichiometric quantities of the above metal nitrates were dissolved in 50 mL distilled water. Then, anhydrous citric acid (Sigma-Aldrich) was added to the solution. The molar ratio of citric acid to total metal nitrate was 1.2. The mixed solution was heated at 80 °C under stirring to evaporate the water to form a gel. Then, the gel was foamed in a muffle furnace at 150 °C for 10 h at a rate of 2 °C min–1. Finally, the dried gel was crushed into powders, calcined in two steps: at 350 °C for 1 h and then at 750 °C for 2 h at a rate of 5 °C min–1. 2.2 Characterization The precursors of LaFeO3-based perovskites after being foamed at 150 °C, were tested by thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TG/DTA) using a SETARAM Setsys Evolution 12 calorimeter in alumina crucibles. Each sample was heated from 25 °C to 950 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1 in flowing air (50 mL min−1). The chemical composition of all samples was determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Horiba Jobin Yvon). Before to the determination, the samples were dissolved in HNO3 and H2SO4 in an oven at 250 °C. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out on a Bruker D8 advance A25 diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154184 nm). Samples were scanned from 10° < 2θ < 80° with a step size of 0.02° and a counting time of 2 s per step. Raman spectra were recorded at room temperature using a LabRam HR Evolution (Horiba Scientific) spectrometer with a 532 nm Ar ion laser equipped with a CCD detector. The measurements were carried out under the microscope with a × 50 objective. Before the measurement, a silicon sheet was used to calibrate the laser (520.7 nm). The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded by a PerkinElmer FT-IR C92712 spectrometer in attenuated total reflectance (ATR) mode with an instrument resolution of 1 cm−1. Nitrogen adsorption experiments were conducted by Micromeritics TRISTAR II apparatus at − 196 °C. Samples were pretreated at 350 °C for 3 h under vacuum prior to the test. Specific surface area (SSA) was calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) model. Total pore volume (Vp) and mean pore size were analyzed by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. Temperature programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) experiments were analyzed on a Thermo Scientific TPD/R/O 1110 Catalytic Surfaces Analyzer. First, 0.1 g sample was pretreated at 350 °C for 1 h in 5% O2/He at a rate of 10 °C min–1. Then, the sample was cooled down to 50 °C. Lastly, the reduction of the sample was performed in 5% H2/Ar from 50 to 950°C at a rate of 10 °C min–1. Temperature programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD) experiments were conducted in the same apparatus used for the H2-TPR runs. First, 0.1 g sample was pretreated at 350 °C for 1 h in 5% O2/He at a rate of 10 °C min–1. Then, the sample was cooled down to 50 °C. Next, the sample was treated in 5% O2/He at 50 °C for 30 min and flushed with pure helium for 30 min. Finally, the desorption of the sample was performed in He from 50 to 950 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1. 2.3 Catalytic test The propene total oxidation tests over the catalysts (0.1 g, ~ 315 µm, diluted with 0.5 g SiC) were conducted in a U-shape quartz flow reactor (with an inner diameter of 4 mm) with a feed composed of 1000 ppm of propene and 21 vol% oxygen balanced with helium; the total flow rate was controlled at 100 mL min–1, resulting in a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 60,000 mL h–1 gcat –1. The test was operated between 150 and 450 °C, undergoing a stabilizing-heating-aging and cooling process (Fig. S1). Propene, CO and CO2 were detected by gas chromatography (SRA % GC-R3000) coupled with a thermal conductivity detector. The temperature was measured by a thermocouple placed close to the middle of the catalytic bed. Propene conversion (X) was calculated by the formula: X = [ CO 2 ] outlet 3 [ C 3 H 6 ] inlet ∙ 100 % where [ CO 2 ] outlet and [ C 3 H 6 ] inlet refer to the concentrations of outlet CO2 and inlet C3H6, respectively. Considering B-site as the active site, the specific reaction rate (r, s−1) was calculated by the formula: r = F ∙ X n B where F is the molar flow rate (mol s−1), X is the propene conversion (X < 15%), and nB is the molar quantity of B site (mol). Six successive catalytic cycles were performed to evaluate the stability of the selected catalyst. For the long-term durability test, the reaction temperature was maintained at 335 °C for 35 h. Space velocity effect was examined by using 0.1, 0.05, 0.025 g of the catalyst while keeping constant the other conditions. The water effect was checked by introducing 5 vol% H2O into the system, which was generated by bubbling in a water container immersed into a bath maintained at 34 °C. Propene oxidation without oxygen was conducted in the same setup. Thus, 0.1 g of sample mixed with 0.5 g of SiC was first pretreated at 450 °C for 0.5 h in He to remove any impurities that may be adsorbed. Once the sample was cooled down to 50 °C, 1000 ppm of propene balanced with He was introduced into the reactor. The temperature was raised to 450 °C (5 °C min–1), maintained for 1 h and finally dropped to room temperature (5 °C min–1). 2.4 Kinetic study To study the mass transport and diffusion effects, propene oxidation was carried out at 300 °C over LaFeO3 under different WHSV, or under different flow rates (50, 100, 150 mL min–1) while fixing the WHSV at 60,000 mL g–1 h–1. Power-Law equation, widely used to determine the reaction order [41,42], is the simplest kinetic equation to depict the relationship between the specific reaction rate and the concentration of reaction species: − r = k P c 3 H 6 m P O 2 n where k is the reaction constant, m and n are the reaction orders of oxygen and propene, P O 2 and P C 3 H 6 are the partial pressures of oxygen and propene. To determine m value, the oxygen concentration was varied from 1% to 21% while fixing propene concentration at 1000 ppm; to determine n value, propene concentration was changed between 500 and 4000 ppm while maintaining oxygen concentration at 21%. The specific reaction rate was calculated in the temperature range of 180 − 280 °C for which the propene conversion was less than 15%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and textural properties Before synthesizing the perovskite, the tolerance factor, which has been widely used to predict the stability of the perovskite, was calculated for all samples. As shown in Table 1, the tolerance factors of all samples are in the range of 0.8–1.0, indicating good stability of the perovskite structure [43], which provides theoretic feasibility for perovskite synthesis. Moreover, this factor increased after cobalt substitution, suggesting the symmetry enhancement of the samples. To investigate the formation of LaFeO3 during the calcination process, TG/DTA was performed in a flow of air. The resulting curve is depicted in Fig. S2. A typical TG curve was observed for the LaFeO3 precursor. The weight loss below 300 °C was due to the decomposition of the remaining citric acid whereas the subsequent weight loss from 300 to 650 °C was attributed to the decomposition of nitrates and carbonates. When the temperature was above 650 °C, negligible weight loss occurred, indicating the completion of the decomposition and the formation of perovskite [44]. To obtain highly crystallized and stable LaFeO3 perovskite, 750 °C was chosen as the final calcination temperature. The chemical composition of all samples was determined by ICP-OES. The actual formulae of the synthesized samples were calculated and presented in Table 1, which were similar to the theoretical ones. The structures of the as-synthesized perovskites were investigated by XRD analysis. As shown in Fig. 1a, well-crystallized perovskite structures diffraction peaks can be observed for all samples. For LaFeO3 and cobalt substituted samples, they showed the orthorhombic-type LaFeO3 phase (PDF #88–0641). For the LaCoO3 sample, the XRD pattern corresponded to the rhombohedral perovskite-type phase (PDF #84–0848). No diffraction peaks of cobalt oxide or iron oxide occurred in the XRD patterns, indicating the high purity of the samples. To further look into the effect of cobalt introduction, the most intense peaks of all samples were enlarged and displayed in Fig. 1b. As cobalt proportion increased, the peaks gradually shifted to higher 2 theta values, which was caused by the lattice contraction due to the difference in radius between Co3+ (0.610 Å) and Fe3+ (0.645 Å). There is a linear relationship between the 2 theta positions of the main peak and the cobalt content (Fig. 1c). The structural parameters of LaFe1−xCoxO3 obtained from Le-Bail fitting was listed in Table S1, which also indicated the linear contraction of the unit cell after cobalt substitution. The average crystallite sizes of the samples were estimated by the Scherrer equation. As listed in Table 1, smaller crystallites were obtained after cobalt substitution. a tolerance factor calculated by formula t = r A + r O 2 ( r B + r O ) , where rA, rB and rO are the radii of A, B and oxygen. b calculated by ICP-OES results. c average crystallite size calculated by Scherrer equation. d specific surface area calculated from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm. e H2 consumption amount below 550 °C in H2-TPR experiments. f calculated from O2-TPD. To investigate the structure distortion of the perovskites, Raman spectra were collected and shown in Fig. 2. The spectrum of LaFeO3 was similar to that reported in previous studies [45–48]. The peaks at around 102, 158, 265, 294, 430, 500, and 630 cm–1 were assigned to one-phonon scattering in B1 g, Ag, B3 g, Ag, B3 g, and two B2g modes respectively, while those at ~1135 and 1310 cm–1 corresponded to two-phonon scattering [46,47]. The mode below 200 cm–1 was due to the vibration of La sites, while the two peaks at 264 and 293 cm–1 were associated with the FeO6 octahedra tilt mode [49]. In the spectrum of the LaCoO3 sample, two typical peaks at 145 and 403 cm–1 ascribed to the Eg modes of the rhombohedral LaCoO3 perovskite were observed [50]. However, the spectra of Co-substituted LaFeO3 perovskites were quite different from that of LaFeO3 or LaCoO3. The La-site vibrations below 200 cm−1 disappeared, indicating the presence of lattice distortion induced by cobalt substitution. Besides, two new peaks at ~523 and 624 cm–1 appeared, and they shifted to higher frequencies as the cobalt content increased as a consequence of structural distortions and lattice shrinkage after cobalt substitution. This effect was reported in [47] and [50]. The significant differences in Raman spectra would demonstrate the change of the B-site structure accompanied by large lattice distortion [49], which agrees well with the XRD analysis. FTIR spectra of the LaFe1−xCoxO3 perovskites are displayed in Fig. 3. The band at ~560 cm−1 arises from the metal−O stretching vibrations in the octahedral site of LaFeO3 or LaCoO3 perovskite. Regarding the LaFeO3 sample, the band at ~538 cm−1 was assigned to the Fe−O stretching vibration in the FeO6 octahedron, while the bands at ~525 cm−1 and ~580 cm−1 were assigned to Co−O stretching vibrations in the CoO6 octahedron of the LaCoO3 sample. With increasing cobalt content, the band corresponding to Fe−O shifted to higher wavenumber, indicating the increase of Fe−O vibration energy and bond length, and consequently larger lattice distortion [51], which is consistent with the XRD and Raman results. N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were performed to study the textural properties of the samples. As presented in Fig. S3, all samples showed type IV isotherms with hysteresis loop owing to the capillary condensation in mesopores. According to Table 1, the specific surface area of LaFeO3 is 8 m2 g–1, larger than that of LaCoO3 (6 m2 g–1). After substitution, the specific surface area slightly decreased. As discussed in the XRD analysis, smaller crystallite sizes were obtained for the substituted perovskites, which is expected to lead to larger surface areas. However, it seems more severe agglomeration to occur at a higher Co content in the structure, ultimately resulting in smaller surface areas. 3.2 Redox ability and oxygen mobility It is generally believed that the total oxidation of hydrocarbons over perovskites proceeds via a redox mechanism in which the reducibility of the catalysts plays a vital role [52,53]. H2-TPR experiments were performed to study the reducibility of the LaFeO3-based perovskites; the profiles are presented in Fig. 4a, and hydrogen consumption amount are listed in Table 1. Two weak peaks at ~300 °C and 400 °C were observed for the LaFeO3 sample, which might be caused by the reduction of adsorbed oxygen species on the surface of LaFeO3. The reduction peaks observed for LaFeO3 was rather small due to the low reducibility of iron species in the perovskite structure, which has been reported by other studies [54,55]. After cobalt substitution, two intense peaks at 200–350 °C and 350–550 °C appeared. The former was associated with Co3+→Co2+ while the latter was ascribed to Co2+→Co0 [56], which was further evidenced by the reduction profile of the LaCoO3 sample (Fig. S4). The intensity of the two peaks increased with the cobalt content. The H2 consumption amount below 550 °C, which may be related to the catalytic activity, was calculated, and plotted in Fig. 4b as a function of the Co/(Fe+Co) ratio. A good correlation was established between the reducibility and the cobalt proportion, demonstrating that all cobalt species in the perovskites could be reduced at low temperatures, greatly enhancing the reducibility of LaFeO3. Moreover, the peaks appearing above 900 °C due to the reduction of the iron species shifted to lower temperatures as the cobalt content increased, which also suggested the better reducibility of cobalt substituted catalysts. The better reducibility of the Co-substituted perovskite could be due to the easier electron transfer between the unoccupied molecular orbitals in the B sites due to the stronger electronegativity of Co compared to that of Fe [57]. O2-TPD was performed to elucidate the presence of oxygen species on the surface of the catalysts. The results were shown in Fig. 5. Regarding the LaFeO3-based perovskites, the oxygen desorption profiles could be divided into three parts. The first part would correspond to a peak between 100 and 360 °C which was assigned to chemisorbed oxygen species on oxygen vacancies, namely Oα; the second part (Oβ) consisted of two peaks, located at 360 − 525 °C, and 525 − 750 °C, which were ascribed to surface lattice oxygen (O2 - and O-, etc.); the last part (> 750 °C) was due to the desorption of bulk lattice oxygen [31,56]. In the process of catalytic oxidation, the occurrence of low-temperature oxygen species is important. Thus, the desorbed amount of Oα and Oβ1 were integrated, calculated, and listed in Table 1. After cobalt substitution, the oxygen mobility of LaFeO3 was enhanced, as evidenced by the increased amount of Oα and Oβ1, which could participate in the oxidation process and contribute to the catalytic activity. The desorbed amount of Oβ1 increased with cobalt doping, which is consistent with the FITR analysis, suggesting that the Co−O bond in the substituted LaFeO3 perovskites tended to be weaker when cobalt doping increased, thus generating more oxygen species on the surface and promoting the oxidation of hydrocarbons. Summarizing, cobalt doping into the structure of LaFeO3 led to significantly higher redox ability and potential better performance in propene oxidation. 3.3 Catalytic activity The catalytic performance of the LaFe1−xCoxO3 perovskites was evaluated in the total oxidation of propene, a model VOC. First, the mass transport limitation and diffusion effects of the catalysts were investigated over LaFeO3, which was considered a representative catalyst. As shown in Fig. S5a, a similar propene oxidation rate was obtained at 300 °C regardless of the flow rate, thus discarding the presence of mass transport limitations. The linear relationship between the reaction rate and the space velocity depicted in Fig. S5b further ruled out the possibility of mass transport limitations and diffusional effects. Fig. S6a shows the light-off curves of the LaFe1−xCoxO3 perovskites for catalytic oxidation of propene. In all cases, the CO2 yield matched with the propene conversion, suggesting an excellent carbon balance. All catalysts reached a full conversion of propene in the tested temperature range. Among them, LaFeO3 obviously showed inferior performance. After introducing cobalt, the performance was greatly enhanced until x = 0.2, further adding cobalt improved the low-temperature performance but hardly contributed to the high-temperature one. LaFe0.7Co0.3O3 exhibited catalytic performance similar to that of LaCoO3 at temperatures lower than 300 °C, whereas better than that observed for LaCoO3 above 300 °C. The values of T50 and T90 for propene oxidation over the tested perovskites are summarized in Table 2. LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 presented a T90 of 345 °C, which is 48 °C lower than that of LaFeO3. To further confirm the performance enhancement provoked by the cobalt substitution, the LaFe1−xCoxO3 catalysts were also tested for propane oxidation (Fig. S6b). Likewise, the propane oxidation performance over LaFeO3 was promoted by cobalt substitution. As it can be checked, the light-off curves of LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 and LaFe0.7Co0.3O3 are pretty similar. However, LaCoO3 performed worse than LaFe0.7Co0.3O3. To better compare the catalytic activity of the LaFe1−xCoxO3 perovskites for propene oxidation, the specific reaction rates were calculated taking B-site (Fe and Co) as the active site. As shown in Fig. 6, the specific reaction rate increased gradually with the cobalt content. Interestingly, the activity of LaFe0.7Co0.3O3 was almost the same as that of LaCoO3 though LaCoO3 possesses superior intrinsic activity if compared to that of LaFeO3. This means that replacing a large part of cobalt with much cheaper iron in La-based perovskites can be a cost-effective strategy for catalyst design. As catalytic oxidation proceeds more readily over a catalyst with lower apparent activation energy (Ea), Ea was calculated from the slope of the Arrhenius curve, being listed in Table 2. The Ea value dropped significantly from 71 kJ mol–1 for LaFeO3 to 58 kJ mol–1 for LaFe0.8Co0.2O3, suggesting that cobalt substitution may change the reaction pathway. In addition, the Ea value of LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 is lower than that of LaCoO3. All the above results would indicate that the cobalt incorporation in LaFeO3 is beneficial for propene oxidation. As aforementioned discussed, the specific surface areas of the catalysts slightly decreased with cobalt substitution, showing that the increase in catalytic activity is not related to the variation of specific surface area. On the other hand, after cobalt substitution, both the reducibility and the oxygen mobility of LaFe1−xCoxO3 were evidently enhanced. Moreover, a good correlation was established between the catalytic activity and the amount of desorbed oxygen species from the surface of the catalysts determined by O2-TPD (Fig. 6b). Propene oxidation experiments in the absence of molecular oxygen were conducted over the LaFe1−xCoxO3 perovskites to explore the surface-active oxygen content and mobility. Fig. 7 displayed the CO2 and CO evolution during the experiments performed. Here, the production of CO2 represents the total oxidation of propene while the produced CO is a result of its partial oxidation [58]. For all perovskites, CO2 production firstly increased with increasing temperatures due to the activation of surface oxygen species and then decreased when the catalysts were aged at 450 °C as a result of the gradual consumption of the activated oxygen species. Finally, almost no CO2 was generated as the temperature decreased to 100 °C. The total amount of CO2 produced during the heating-ageing-cooling run ranks as follows: LaCoO3 > LaFe0.7Co0.3O3 > LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 > LaFe0.9Co0.1O3 > LaFeO3, showing a positive correlation with the cobalt content. The result would indicate that compared with iron, the oxygen species associated with cobalt in the B-site contributed more to the total oxidation of propene. The onset temperature of CO2 production over LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 is around 190 °C, much lower than that over LaFeO3 (ca. 240 °C), suggesting the easier activation and higher mobility of oxygen species after cobalt incorporation. As revealed by O2-TPD, the amount of Oα in LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 was the highest, which may account for its largest CO2 production in the low-temperature range. However, regarding the CO production in Fig. 7b, it started from ~240 °C and experienced a continuous increase even during aging at 450 °C, then decreased gradually to zero as the temperature decreased from 450 to 100 °C, which would indicate that the oxygen species for propene total oxidation to CO2 were different from those for propene partial oxidation to CO over the LaFeO3-based perovskites. Chang et al. [57] demonstrated that the surface-active oxygen species was related to the total oxidation of methane while the lattice oxygen diffused to the surface accounted for the methane partial oxidation to CO. Overall, there was less CO produced for the cobalt substituted catalysts than for the pure LaFeO3, which suggests that cobalt-substitution could promote the oxidation of CO to CO2. In industrial applications, a catalyst is usually subjected to numbers of cycles or long-operating time, which add high requirements on the stability of the catalyst. Herein, LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 with outstanding propene oxidation performance was considered as the reference for the stability analysis next performed. First, six successive heating and cooling cycles of propene oxidation were conducted. As shown in Fig. 8a, the light-off curve of LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 in the sixth cycle coincided well with that in the first cycle, demonstrating the excellent reusability of LaFe0.8Co0.2O3. Then, the on-stream reaction experiment was performed over LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 at 335 °C for 35 h. As depicted in Fig. 8b, the propene conversion was well maintained at ~84% during the testing period of 35 h. In addition, the influence of space velocity was checked (Fig. 8c) by changing the mass of catalysts, the WHSV was varied from 60,000 to 24,0000 mL g–1 h–1. As expected, the catalytic performance of LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 decreased with increasing values of WHSV due to the shortened contact time of reactant molecules with the catalyst. Nevertheless, 100% conversion was still achieved over LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 below 450 °C even under a high value of WHSV of 24,0000 mL g–1 h–1. Water-resistance is another key issue in practical applications. Propene oxidation over LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 was tested in dry condition first, then 5 vol% of water vapor was introduced into the reaction system, after removing water vapor, a new catalytic cycle under dry condition was conducted again. As displayed in Fig. 8d, with water vapor introduced into the system, the catalytic performance obviously decreased. The T90 of LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 was 44 °C higher than that observed for dry condition. Fortunately, this inhibiting effect on catalytic activity was reversible after removing water vapor from the feeding gas. The reversible inhibition effect of water on propene oxidation was further confirmed over LaFeO3 (Fig. S7). As reported in the literature [59], this phenomenon would be explained by the competitive adsorption among water vapor, oxygen and propene, which makes it more difficult for propene and oxygen to adsorb and to be activated on the active sites. Generally speaking, various VOCs coexist in real industrial emissions. To investigate the possible mutual effect in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs mixtures, 1000 ppm of propene and 1000 ppm of propane were simultaneously introduced into the reaction system by using LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 as the catalyst. Fig. S8 compared the light-off curves of propene and propane oxidation for their single or combined oxidations. When they were simultaneously oxidized the catalytic conversion of both propene and propane decreased, indicating a mutual inhibition effect, possibly due to the competitive adsorption or activation of propene and propane over the active sites of LaFe0.8Co0.2O3. Such mutual inhibition was also reported in the catalytic oxidation of a toluene and acetone mixture over Pt/TiO2 catalyst, which was attributed to a decrease in the adsorption capacity of the catalyst [60]. In our case, the decrease in the propene conversion was less than that in the propane one, thus suggesting a stronger interaction between propene and the active sites of LaFe0.8Co0.2O3. 3.4 Kinetic study The propene oxidation performance of LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 was evaluated under different inlet concentrations of oxygen (1 −21 vol%) and propene (500 −4000 ppm), as presented in Fig. S9. The light-off curves shifted to lower temperature region with the increase of oxygen concentration and to higher temperatures with the increase of propene one. Anyway, the propene concentration had a greater impact on propene oxidation than that of oxygen. In all cases, full conversion of propene can be achieved below 400 °C, which would demonstrate that the catalyst could work under realistic conditions with various reactant concentrations. The apparent activation energy and pre-exponential factor under different conditions were calculated by Arrhenius equation and the results are summarized in Table S2. It has been reported that the apparent activation energy is related to the reaction pathway whereas the pre-exponential factor (A) is linked to the number of active sites [61]. When varying the oxygen concentration, almost no difference was observed for the Ea and lnA values, which may be explained by the excessive amount of oxygen concentration used for propene oxidation. However, in the case of using different propene concentrations, the Ea value increases with the propene concentration while the lnA value did the opposite. One possible reason is that a high concentration of propene restricts the propene oxidation rate due to the limited number of active sites present on the surface of the catalysts. The reaction orders of oxygen and propene over LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 were obtained on the basis of the Power-Law model. As depicted in Fig. 9, the reaction orders were reflected by the slopes of the fitting curves. All correlation coefficients (R2) were above 0.95, indicating the good fitting of the data. The reaction orders with respect to oxygen (0.197 −0.205) and propene (0.303 −0.332) were almost constant at different temperatures. A similar reaction order of propene (0.27) was reported over Cu-Co binary oxide for propene oxidation in excess oxygen condition, in which the propene adsorption was claimed as the determinate step of propene oxidation [62]. On the other hand, for platinum-group catalysts, it is commonly found that the propene reaction order was negative while the oxygen order was positive, which suggested the stronger adsorption of propene than oxygen on the surface of noble metal [63]. In our case, the lower reaction order of oxygen (~0.2) than propene (~0.3) would indicate that the propene oxidation over LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 is more dependent on propene than on oxygen. Considering the rich oxygen concentration in the feed used in the study, propene adsorption/activation might be the rate-determining step for propene oxidation over LaFe0.8Co0.2O3. 4 Conclusions In this work, a series of LaFe1−xCoxO3 perovskites, with specific surface areas of 6–10 m2 g−1 and average crystallite sizes of 26–49 nm, were synthesized via a citrate method and used for propene total oxidation. Various characterizations showed that cobalt was introduced into LaFeO3 while maintaining the structure. With increasing cobalt content from 0.1 to 0.3, the surface area slightly decreased while the lattice distortion increased. Cobalt incorporation could greatly enhance the low-temperature reducibility and the oxygen mobility of the perovskite thus leading to better catalytic performance. A good correlation was established between the catalytic activity and the amount of the active oxygen species. As a cost-effective catalyst (T90 = 345 °C, Ea = 58 kJ mol–1), LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 exhibited outstanding stability in cycling and long-term tests, as well as good water resistance being a potential candidate catalyst for industrial applications. Moreover, the Power-Law model provided fairly good fits to the kinetic data (R2 > 0.95) and suggested that the reaction order of oxygen and propene over LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 were 0.2 and 0.3, respectively. coredata.dc:description: To develop robust and cost-effective catalysts for propene total oxidation, LaFe1−xCoxO3 (x = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 1) perovskites were prepared via a citrate sol-gel method. XRD, FTIR and Raman analyses suggested that after cobalt substitution, the LaFeO3 structure was well maintained, whereas abundant lattice distortions were generated accompanied by weaker Fe−O bond. H2-TPR and O2-TPD results demonstrated that cobalt incorporation led to better reducibility and higher oxygen mobility of the oxides. The propene oxidation activity of the catalysts was found to increase with the cobalt content, which correlated well with the amount of surface-active oxygen species. The optimal catalyst LaFe0.8Co0.2O3 presented comparable activity to LaCoO3 at much lower cost. Moreover, it showed excellent cyclability (6 cycles) and stability (35 h), decent performance at high space velocity (24,0000 mL g–1 h–1) or in the presence of 5 vol% water, thereby being a promising candidate for industrial application.
coredata.dc:title: Boosting propene oxidation activity over LaFeO3 perovskite catalysts by cobalt substitution
